pullRequest.body:
We prove the following result that, if `f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ` satisfies that `(‚àë k ‚àà Icc 1 n, f k) / n` tends to some complex number `l` when `n ‚Üí ‚àû` and that the L-series `LSeries f` converges for all `s : ‚Ñù` such that `1 < s`. Then  `(s - 1) * LSeries f s` tends to `l` when `s ‚Üí 1` with `1 < s`.

---

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

- ...

Deletions:

- ...

below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

> Hi Xavier,
> 
> I won't have time to actually try compiling this and experimenting with it for a day or two, so here are some stylistic comments based only on reading the code on github.

Thanks for the first comments. Don't worry, there is no need to hurry.

Hi Xavier, 

I won't have time to actually try compiling this and experimenting with it for a day or two, so here are some stylistic comments based only on reading the code on github.

Hi Xavier, 

I won't have time to actually try compiling this and experimenting with it for a day or two, so here are some stylistic comments based only on reading the code on github.
merge artifact?
I think using the "mapsto" arrow is preferred style
Using `variable` with Prop-valued hypotheses tends to be a bit clumsy; you have to `include` them every time, so it's probably simpler just to reproduce the hypothesis in each lemma
can `linarith` handle this?
I would personally find it clearer if the proofs of the calc steps were interleaved between the calc lines rather than being stored up and done at the end.
Same comment here. I suggest **not** indenting the `calc` steps, so they stand out visually from the proofs indented in between.
can we use `continuity` or `fun_prop` here?
The body of the `suffices` is shorter than the remaining proof, so maybe use `have`?
If you do `filter_upwards [eventually_ge_atTop T, eventually_ge_atTop 0] with t ht ht'` you don't need to make `ht'` separately.
`rw [show ... by rw [...]]` seems convoluted
Is it possible that these fiddly inequality manipulations could be avoided by using a "softer" approach working with filters, rather than rewriting everything in terms of epsilons?

pullRequest.title: feat(NumberTheory/LSeries): results involving partial sums of coefficients (part 2)
